step_text: Make a soft dough with wheat flour and water; rest 15 minutes.
Mash boiled potatoes, add chopped chillies, coriander, garam masala and salt.
Roll dough into small circle, place potato filling, seal and roll gently into paratha.
Cook on tawa with ghee until golden brown on both sides; serve hot with curd or pickle.
Wash and soak basmati rice for 30 minutes.
Marinate chicken with yogurt, ginger-garlic paste, biryani masala, red chilli, turmeric and salt for at least 30 minutes.
Fry onions until deep golden and set aside. Reserve some for garnish.
Par-cook rice in salted boiling water till 70% done; drain and keep aside.
In a heavy bottom pan, heat ghee and oil, add whole spices and sauté for 30 seconds.
Add marinated chicken and cook until chicken is 80% done and oil separates.
Layer half the rice over chicken, sprinkle half of mint, coriander and fried onions. Repeat layers.
Dissolve saffron in warm milk and drizzle on top, add ghee.
Seal the pan with dough or tight lid and cook on low flame (dum) for 25-30 minutes.
Turn off heat and rest for 10 minutes before opening. Gently mix layers and serve hot with raita.
Heat oil, sauté onions until golden; add ginger-garlic paste and cook until raw smell disappears.
Add tomato puree and cook until oil separates.
Add spices (turmeric, chilli, coriander) and mix; add chicken pieces and mix to coat.
Add water to cover chicken partly, simmer on medium-low for 25-30 minutes until chicken is cooked and gravy thickens.
Stir in garam masala, garnish with coriander and serve hot with rice or roti.
Season chicken with taco spice and a pinch of salt; sauté in hot oil until cooked through.
Warm tortillas and layer with lettuce, chicken, tomato and onion.
Top with sour cream or salsa and serve immediately.
Preheat oven to 180°C (350°F). Grease and line a 8-inch cake pan.
In a bowl, sift flour, cocoa, baking powder, baking soda and salt.
In another bowl whisk eggs, sugar, oil and vanilla; mix with dry ingredients alternating with milk.
Stir in hot water to make a smooth batter; pour into prepared pan and bake for 28-32 minutes until a skewer comes out clean.
Cool, remove from pan and frost or dust with cocoa as desired.
Pressure cook soaked chickpeas with salt until soft (about 6-7 whistles).
Heat oil, add chopped onions and sauté until golden; add ginger-garlic paste and sauté briefly.
Add tomato puree and cook until oil separates; add chole masala, red chilli and cook 1-2 minutes.
Add cooked chickpeas, some of the cooking water, simmer for 10-12 minutes; add amchur and garnish with coriander.
Rinse dal and cook with turmeric and water until soft (pressure cook 3-4 whistles).
Mash dal to desired consistency and simmer for 4-5 minutes.
In a small pan, heat ghee, add cumin seeds, slit red chilli, garlic and curry leaves; sauté until garlic is golden.
Pour tadka over dal, mix well, garnish with coriander and serve with rice or roti.
Heat wok, add oil and scramble beaten eggs quickly; remove and set aside.
Add more oil, sauté garlic, then add cooked rice and toss on high heat.
Add soy sauce, salt, pepper and mix; fold in scrambled eggs and spring onions before serving.
Make a smooth dough from milk powder, flour and milk; divide into small smooth balls without cracks.
Heat sugar and water to make a one-string syrup; add crushed cardamom and a dash of rose water.
Deep fry balls on low-medium heat until golden brown; drain briefly and transfer into warm sugar syrup. Let soak for 1-2 hours before serving.
Steam idlis from batter in idli moulds for 10–12 minutes until spongy.
Cook toor dal until soft and mash or blend to smooth consistency.
In a pan, sauté vegetables, add sambar powder and tamarind pulp with water, bring to boil.
Add cooked dal, simmer 7–8 minutes, finish with tadka of mustard seeds and curry leaves.
Serve hot idlis with sambar and coconut chutney.
Wash rice and soak 15 minutes; drain.
Bring milk to a boil in a heavy-bottom pan; add rice and simmer on low, stirring frequently.
Cook until rice is soft and milk reduces to creamy consistency (25-30 minutes).
Add sugar, cardamom, saffron, nuts and raisins; simmer 2-3 minutes more and serve warm or chilled.
Wash rice, moong dal and toor dal thoroughly. Soak in water for 15 minutes, then drain.
Peel and chop onions; chop tomatoes, green chilies and dice potatoes into small cubes. Keep curry leaves whole and finely chop coriander for garnish.
Place a 3–5 L pressure cooker on medium flame. Warm the cooker for 30–60 seconds and add oil; allow it to heat until it shimmers.
Add jeera and mustard seeds. Let them splutter for 20–30 seconds but do not burn.
Add chopped onions and green chilies. Sauté for 3–4 minutes until onions turn light golden, stirring continuously.
Add chopped tomato and cook for 1–2 minutes until tomatoes soften and turn pulpy.
Add salt, red chilli powder, turmeric, ginger-garlic paste, curry leaves and potato cubes. Mix and cook for 4–5 minutes to remove raw spice smell.
Add soaked and drained rice, moong dal and toor dal. Mix gently to avoid breaking rice grains.
Pour 4 cups of water into the cooker and stir once. Check salt and adjust.
Close the cooker lid and place the whistle. Cook on medium flame for 3 whistles (~10–12 minutes).
Turn off the gas and allow the pressure to release naturally. Do not open immediately.
Open the lid carefully once pressure is released. Add chopped coriander, mix gently and serve hot with ghee or curd.
Soak rice and urad dal with fenugreek separately for 4–6 hours. Grind to a smooth batter, mix and ferment overnight (8–12 hours).
Boil potatoes, peel and mash lightly; in a pan heat oil, add mustard seeds, curry leaves and onions, sauté until soft.
Add turmeric and chopped green chillies, add mashed potatoes, salt and mix; cook 2–3 minutes and finish with coriander.
Heat a non-stick tawa, pour a ladle of batter and spread into a thin circle; drizzle oil around edges.
When dosa edges lift and bottom is golden, place potato masala on one side and fold; serve hot with sambar and chutney.
Soak cashews in warm water for 15 minutes and grind to a smooth paste with a tablespoon of water.
Heat butter and oil in a heavy-bottom pan on medium flame. Add finely chopped onions and sauté until translucent (4-5 minutes).
Add ginger-garlic paste and sauté for 30 seconds until raw smell disappears.
Add tomato puree and cook on medium heat until oil separates from the masala (6-7 minutes).
Add Kashmiri red chilli, turmeric, coriander powder and salt. Mix well and cook for 1 minute.
Stir in the cashew paste and 1/2 cup water. Cook for 2-3 minutes on low heat, stirring continuously.
Add paneer cubes gently and simmer for 3 minutes so paneer absorbs the gravy flavors.
Stir in fresh cream, kasuri methi (crushed) and garam masala. Cook for 1 minute.
Add sugar to balance the acidity and taste; adjust salt if necessary.
Turn off the heat, garnish with chopped coriander and a drizzle of cream.
Serve hot with naan, roti or jeera rice.
Cook pasta according to package instructions until al dente; reserve 1/4 cup pasta water.
In a pan, melt butter, sauté garlic briefly then add heavy cream and simmer 2 minutes.
Stir in grated parmesan until melted and smooth. Add cooked pasta and toss; use reserved pasta water to adjust consistency.
Season with salt and pepper, garnish with parsley and serve immediately.
Boil potatoes, cauliflower and peas until soft; mash roughly.
In a large pan, heat butter and oil; sauté chopped onions until golden.
Add tomato puree and cook until oil separates; add pav bhaji masala and salt.
Add mashed vegetables, adjust water and simmer for 8-10 minutes, mashing well to a thick consistency.
Serve hot with buttered pav, chopped onions, coriander and lemon wedges.
Heat oil in a pot; sauté onions and garlic until soft.
Add carrots and capsicum and sauté for 1-2 minutes.
Add sweet corn and vegetable stock; bring to a gentle boil.
Mix cornflour with 3 tbsp water to make a slurry; slowly add to the soup while stirring to thicken.
If using egg, slowly pour beaten egg in a thin stream while stirring to create egg ribbons.
Season with salt and pepper, garnish with spring onion and serve hot.
Blanch tomatoes in boiling water for 2 minutes, peel and roughly chop.
Heat oil in a saucepan, sauté chopped onions and garlic until translucent.
Add chopped tomatoes and cook for 5-6 minutes until soft.
Add stock, sugar and basil leaves; simmer for 10 minutes.
Blend the soup until smooth, strain if desired, return to pot and adjust seasoning.
Stir in a tablespoon of cream if using, garnish with basil and serve with croutons.
Warm tortillas on a pan for 20 seconds each to soften.
Mix rice, beans, corn, sautéed onion and pepper, salsa and cheese.
Place filling on tortilla, fold edges and roll tightly. Serve warm with salsa.
Boil noodles according to packet instructions with a little oil; drain, rinse in cold water and toss with a drop of oil to prevent sticking.
Heat wok, add oil and smashed garlic; sauté quickly.
Add sliced onion and green chillies; stir-fry 1 minute until translucent.
Add shredded cabbage, carrots and capsicum; stir-fry on high heat for 2-3 minutes so vegetables remain crisp.
Add soy sauce, chilli sauce, vinegar, salt and pepper; toss well.
Add noodles and toss vigorously on high heat for 1-2 minutes so sauces coat noodles evenly.
Finish with spring onion greens and serve immediately.
Combine shredded cabbage, carrot, capsicum with salt, pepper, cornflour and maida; mix to form a stiff mixture.
Shape mixture into small balls (manchurian balls) and deep fry in hot oil until golden brown; drain on paper towel.
For gravy, heat 2 tbsp oil in a pan; add minced garlic and ginger and sauté until aromatic.
Add chopped onion and sauté until soft; add ketchup, soy sauce and vinegar.
Add 1 cup water and bring to a simmer. Mix cornflour with a little water and add to thicken the gravy to desired consistency.
Add fried manchurian balls to the gravy and simmer for 2-3 minutes so flavors combine.
Garnish with chopped spring onion and serve hot with fried rice or noodles.
